title: Anterolateral Leg Alopecia: Common but Commonly Ignored
patient: A 46-year-old man presented with a 2-year history of reducing hair density affecting the lower legs. There was no history of trauma preceding the onset of hair loss. He has male pattern hair loss and was taking tetracycline as required for rosacea. He was otherwise well with no known allergies. On further questioning, he reported no other body hair loss, rashes or associated symptoms. There was no loss of libido, or erectile dysfunction to suggest androgen deficiency. He has no family history of hair loss or autoimmune disease. The patient had been treated with topical antifungals and topical steroids prior to referral with no improvement.\nPhysical examination revealed nonscarring hair loss confined to the anterolateral area of lower legs bilaterally []. There were no signs of active inflammation. Dermoscopic examination showed no broken or exclamation mark hairs. His feet were warm with good peripheral pulses. He has classic Norwood-Hamilton Grade IV male pattern hair loss.\nBased on the history and clinical findings, the patient was diagnosed with anterolateral leg alopecia. He was reassured about the benign nature of this condition with no further treatment was given. Diagnostic skin biopsy was declined.
